授業目的: This course provides an in-depth analysis of Canadian business culture, setting it against the backdrop of Japanese practices. It investigates leadership models, legal frameworks, recruitment strategies, and the effects of cultural diversity, offering students a nuanced understanding of the distinct and overlapping aspects that define business operations and workplace climates in Canada and Japan. The course will offer opportunities to apply this knowledge to various business cases and scenarios. The course does NOT require previous knowledge of business, management, or psychology. The course will primarily involve lecture style format, but participation and discussion among the students is welcome and encouraged.
到達目標:
• Students will gain a comprehensive understanding of the fundamentals of Canadian business culture.
• Students will develop the skills to apply a cross-cultural framework for analyzing organizational behavior in both Canada and Japan, highlighting differences and synergies.
• Students will acquire the competency to critically analyze and reflect on diverse business cultures through structured assessments, enabling practical application of theoretical knowledge to real-world scenarios.
授業方法: The course is designed as an in-person engagement, combining traditional lectures with a range of in-class activities to enhance learning. Throughout the term, LUNA will serve as the central hub for disseminating homework assignments, handouts, and critical dates for exams and project submissions. Active participation is expected from students in discussions, case studies, and various group activities that form an integral part of the class sessions. This participatory approach is aimed at deepening understanding and fostering a collaborative learning environment.
